text:
Wow! These scones are awesome! My first time to make scones and they were a big hit at our bible study. I added 1tsp of cinnamon & 1/4 tsp of nutmeg and a little vanilla. The recipe said that this makes 12 scones, so I divided the dough into 12 balls. Then shaped each ball into a triangle. They came out huge, so once they were out of the oven I cut them in half, which was perfect. I used rasins for 1/2 of the dough. I added chocolate chip to a couple of scones, and fresh blackberries to a few (I cut the blackberries into smaller pieces because they were large). If adding fresh fruit to your scones, I would recommend shaping your dough into a square, then put the fresh fruit into 1/2 side, then fold the other half over the fruit into a triangle shape. That way you won't smash the berries too much. It took several extra minutes baking time. This is a keeper:-)

text:
This is a very tasty recipe. The consistency is a bit lighter than traditional scones, but I personally like that. The only changes I made were to use fresh, frozen cranberries instead of raisins, and I brushed the tops with milk and sprinkled with sugar before baking. My only comments are that these should be cut up into more than 12 wedges unless you like huge scones. If you want something you can cut in half to spread jam, etc. on, I would recommend using a round cookie cutter instead. Also, because I cut mine into 12 large wedges as specified, it took much longer than 15 minutes for them to bake.

Thanks for this recipe! My 6 year old daughter and I enjoyed making together.

These were everything I thought they would be after all the great reviews! I made the recipe as stated, split the batter and made 1/2 the batch w/ mini chocolate chips and 1/2 with Peanut butter chips(Honestly the Choc. Chips ones disappeared WAY faster than the PB ones!) If you have kids or you love s'mores, try adding in cut up mini marshmallows, chocolate chips and small pieces of graham crackers- YUMMY! Don't forget to not play with the dough too much!...had to come back to add this in: I made some last night with a mix of frozen berries, and made a glaze with confectioners sugar and Cruzan mango rum- SO GOOD! I also made a paste with cinnamon, sugar and melted butter, pressed the dough out thin and ten spread the paste over the dough. I then folded the edges in to form it into the circle to cut the slices. I made a glaze for those w/ milk and conf. sugar. They were perfect! a great replacement for cinnamon rolls :)

These are great! I wanted to make a scone-mix-in-a-jar to give as gifts this year, and didn't find one I liked.  So I tried this one!  I was worried about not being able to make the sour cream mixture (since the baking soda would already be mixed in the jar) and how that would effect the recipe.  I just mixed in the dry ingredients, added the wet, and they still came out fantastic! Since I was experimenting, I only made half a recipe.  I left out the raisins and added a generous tablespoon of cinnamon to compliment the apple butter we are also giving.  I highly reccommend using cinnamon! So tastey!!

text:
My first attempt at scones.  The dough was too crumbly to roll out - the butter may have been too cold (I grated frozen butter into the flour) - so I just scooped the dough out with my hands, molded it into a ball, and pressed it into a thick circle on the cookie sheet.  I used chocolate chips instead of raisins, and it turned out great!  Very buttery and crumbly, but moist.  I dipped pieces in melted vanilla ice cream - decadent!  Another reader had problems with the scones drying out the next day, but I stored mine in a plastic bag and they were fine.

Delicious.   What a great recipe.   I don't have a good track record with baking and this turned out perfect.   Don't let the crumbly texture after you have added the sour cream mixture to the dry ingredients scare you.   I just pressed it together a bit before turning it out on the counter and then kneeded it as the recipe instructs.    We served them warm with butter. They took approximately 20 mins to brown in my oven.   We put the leftovers in an airtight container and they tasted great the next day.

WOW! These are absolutely, by FAR, THE best scones Ive ever made! The author (Rob) hit it right on the head when he said Simply the best anywhere!.  Soooo simply and delicious ~ even my 5-1/2 year old ate them (three, right out of the oven!). I opted to make them about  thick instead.  I ended up with 19 scones (nothing wrong with that!) and baking them for less time (about 8-9 minutes). Cant I give these tasty treats a ten star rating?

This was my first attempt at scones.  I'm giving it a five because my family just loved them.  I did change the recipe a bit so the rating may be a bit unfair???  I only had about 1/3 c. lite sour cream so I used that with plain lowfat yogart.  I also added frozen blueberries...kind of an ugly mistake.  The flavor was good and moist but they were bluish gray due to the thick dough and the mixing in of the berries.  Next time I'll try mixing in chocolate chips because I think that will go over better than the raisins.  I had to bake them 10 minutes longer probably because of the berries and they spread out on the pan...also probably because of the berries.  The dough is just too thick to mix in any kind of fresh fruit and I didn't realise that until it was too late.

I made these scones for a brunch and they were delicious.  I added mini choc chips and spinkled cinamon sugar over the top.  I cut about 20-22 triangles from this 12 serving recipe.  I rolled out the dough, cut stripes and then triangles with 3" sides.  Consider doing the same if these are to be served at a brunch or something becaue otherwise they are just too big. People want to sample a bit of this and a bit of that at a brunch- so it's better to make them smaller.  It was nice because it feeds a crowd.

country:

text:
I'm giving this 5 stars if you follow the directions with a couple differences. I just now made this recipe pre-mixing the sour cream and baking soda, and also with butter that had been sitting out about 20 min -- big mistake!

Other times these have come out perfect, like THE BEST scone, flaky and incredible texture. Raves from everyone. This time, premixing the sour cream and with slightly less than fresh outta the fridge butter, they are... notably less good. As one other reviewer noted, "more like a muffin," alas.

Tips:
- KEEP THE BUTTER REALLY COLD
- DON'T PREMIX THE SOUR CREAM + BAKING SODA. Just mix dry things, then cut in butter, add sour cream and egg. It is VERY crumbly if you do it this way. I shape this recipe into two rounds, you really need to press it together but the butter will make them stick, but barely. Then cut into 6 triangles then cut each in half; I end up with 24 smaller triangles.

Add your extras after your mix, I use blueberries sometimes, or make cinnamon chips, or sometimes a "savory" verion by adding ham, cheddar, and green onion. They are ALL KILLER if you get that texture right!

text:
I made these tasty scones twice and the second time I used my food processor.  That made it so much easier!   As I dumped out the dough I added a cup of white chocolate chips and worked that into the dough.  Then I split the dough into fourths and formed each section into a six inch circle.   I then spooned raspberry jelly on one surface and then placed a second circle on top.   It was somewhat equal.  :)  I cut 8 pie-like wedge pieces then placed them on an air-bake cookie sheet.  (my other cookie sheet burned the bottom before the middle was done!). 
I repeated for the other two circles, making a total of 16 scones.   To make prettier, I drizzled white chocolate on the top.  They were fabulous.  
I gave them as gifts.

text:
These scones are amazing! When I make them, everyone that eats them raves about them. I follow the recipe pretty close, except adding a teaspoon vanilla.  I also mix the baking soda in with the sour cream as suggested by one of the reviews. One review also suggested softening the butter and I would urge everyone to NOT do that unless you want flat scones.  The butter should be cold and cut into the flour just like most pastries. I use my food processor. Makes a huge difference in the outcome.  Thank you for the wonderful recipe!

text:
I made these for the first time today.  The flavor is delicious but they certainly were not baked after 15 minutes at 350 degrees.  I boosted the temp to 375 after 10 minutes and had to leave them in for an addiitonal 10 minutes until they were golden brown.  I hadn't read the suggestion to divide the dough into at least 2 parts but that certainly should be part of the recipe because these are too large when only 12 are made from the one round.
My caveat on these, and the reason for only 4 stars is that they are really too rich.  I think the butter could be reduced to 3/4 C.  They are so very soft they can't be sliced and they spread out so much they lost their shape.  Does anyone else have a suggestion for how to decrease the butter but still keep them buttery tasting?
I used currants instead of raisins.

This is my family's #1 favorite recipe.  Needless to say, I have made these scones countless times for home. They are also very, very popular with my coworkers!

text:
I wanted to do a trial run for a scone recipe as I  prepare for my daughter's sorority tea later this week.   I can not imagine how this recipe could be any better.  Absolutely delicious.  A couple of hints - make sure the butter is fridge cold, cut up in small squares and work the butter through the flour with your hands until the consistency is like rough cornmeal.  Everything will work together nicely and you will barely need flour to roll the dough out.   I added in blueberry infused cranberries instead of the raisins and after coming out of the oven, I drizzled the tops with an icing made of confec. sugar and fresh lemon juice.  I also found that the scones were too large so I used a quarter of the dough at a time, cut it like pizza to make smaller, cuter  triangles.

I just made this recipe exactly as written (without the optional raisins) and paired it with the devonshire cream recipe from this site and it was amazing.  Our guests were raving about these scones.  They were so simple to make!  I almost felt guilty accepting the heaping praises knowing that very little effort was involved.

text:
My entire family (including 3 teenagers) loved these scones, but you have to be a fan of dense (not light and crumbly) scones, which we are.  A few things:  1.  At the kneading stage, the dough is definitely dry but comes together after a minute of kneading. 2.  I roughly formed the scones in circles/mounds with my hands and they had a nice, rustic look to them once out of the oven.  MUCH easier than rolling and slicing. 2. I baked the first batch for 13 minutes and the centers were still wet.  I baked the second half of the recipe for 20 minutes and they turned out fully baked and nicely browned with crisp edges.  Next time I make these, I'm going to try adding dried cherries or chocolate chips, which I think will work great in this tasty recipe.

text:
Followed the recipe exactly as written, however I didn't have quite 1 cup of sour cream (probably 3/4 cup), and when I went to start kneading the dough it was way too dry. So I added just a small amount of milk.  Also brushed egg wash on them and baked them for about 20 minutes 350 degrees. Ate with butter and homemade strawberry jam.  These scones were the best scones I have ever eaten.  I'll be making these for years to come!

Addendum: second time making this recipe. Still very good, however I would cut them smaller to make 24 scones instead of 12. Next time I will add some cinnamon to the batter (cinnamon raisin scones) and chill the dough for about an hour before rolling and cutting them out. I forgot the egg wash this time (a mistake- it makes a big difference in the golden brown color on top!) I think they require a few more minutes in the oven (maybe 20?) then I will top with a powder sugar/milk glaze to up the sweetness factor. Overall a really good, basic recipe. I'd like to do a raspberry white chocolate recipe next! I'll let you know how it turns out!

text:
i have the hardest time following any recipe and mostly use them for guidelines, so i seldom rate them.  i thought they turned out great, even though after mixing i wasn't sure the dough would hold together. This recipe was pretty much followed with the following exceptions. i didn't have a full cup of sour cream so i added plain yogurt to make up the difference, i didn't have cream of tartar, so i added 1/4 tsp lemon juice to the egg along with 1 tsp vanilla. i mixed the sour cream and baking soda and then got distracted so it actually sat for quite some time. I also didn't have a full cup of butter, so i used 1/2 cup butter and just under 1/2 cup of vegetable oil. After mixing the wet and dry ingredients, i divided the batter in half, and added dried cranberries, fresh mandarin oranges, walnuts, cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice to one and sausage, broccoli, and goat cheese to the other. i didn't pay attention to how many slices you were supposed to cut the patted circle into and only made 6 out of each one. instead of kneading i just sort of smashed the dough into a ball , flattening and reforming a few times. I had to increase the baking time to 35 min to compensate for the larger size, but they turned out perfect. I only cooked half of each batch, and have frozen the rest for cooking later. Thanks for a wonderful recipe, my first attempt at scones were great thanks to this recipe.

text:
My God these scones were AMAZING! To make them my own, I added 1/4 cup of fresh squeezed orange juice, the zest of two oranges, and 1 cup of craisins. After turning the dough out I divided it in half and made two 3/4" thick rounds, and cut each into 6 triangles. I brushed the top with a little bit of butter and baked till the top was a VERY light golden color. I couldn't WAIT to dig in. It was so light and fluffy, the orange scent was wonderful, and it was just the right amount of flaky. Even my husband, who dislikes scones, devoured 2 of them for breakfast. Will make again and again!

text:
Recipe was super simple to whip up. Dough was good consistency to work with. I made a double batch, added fresh firm blueberries to one full batch (mixed them in super gently and not one popped), lemon extract, lemon rind and poppy seeds to 1/2 of the second batch and for the final 1/2 batch of dough I added currents, orange rind, orange extract, grand marnier, allspice and cardamom. Instead of cutting into pie slices from 1 large mound of dough, I used two large spoons and scooped out large globs of dough. I left a couple inches between the mounds of dough for expansion while cooking. One other thing I did, after reading some reviews about excessive spreading of dough while cooking; I used 1/2 crisco instead of all butter and I added an extra egg to my double batch. This kept the dough from spreading as much. I scooped dough mounds onto a cookie sheet lined with wax paper and froze them for later use. The other half of my dough I cooked on parchment paper which eliminated the need to grease the cookie sheet.  I cooked the dough an additional 10 minutes, 25 min total, since my dough mounds were higher than if I'd cut pie shapes. This left them a nice touch of brown. Great base recipe that can be changed to your tastes.

These are wonderful, and so easy!  My husband is not a raisin fan, but had a cranberry/orange scone at Starbucks and I just couldn't be out done by them!  These were 10 times better.  I used 1 C dried cranberries, the zest of an orange and pumpkin pie spice to taste (about 1 tsp.).  They would be just as great with chocolate chips or plain old cinnamon sugar. (Regarding the butter comments, I ALWAYS use Land O' Lakes salted butter no matter what a recipe calls for.  If a recipe calls for salt in addition, I just omit it and I haven't gone wrong yet.)

text:
I have a fantastic scone recipe that I have been making for my family that is a wonderful flaky scone. I decided to switch it up a little and try this recipe this morning because of all the rave reviews. I'm sorry to say that it wasn't quite what I was expecting. These did not have the flaky consistency that I was expecting, I would try to say somewhere between a scone and a dense cake - leaning on the cake side. These were also just WAY too sweet for my taste, AND my kids. I made the recipe to the letter, with the exception of making half plain and the other half putting in some chocolate chips. Oh my gosh the sugar rush! These are perfectly wonderful if they are to be served in Starbucks or some other coffee shop as more of a pastry, but for myself and my family for breakfast, we prefer our scone recipe from The Ultimate Southern Living cookbook. My recipe has a ratio of 3 1/2 cups of flour with only 1/4 cup of sugar. Also, after 15 minutes in the oven they were not getting that firm and slightly tan coloring on the top, so I upped the temp to 400 for another 10 minutes or so. Grandma's recipe is certainly good if you have a sweet tooth, but I guess we don't, at least not first thing in the morning for breakfast.

text:
These are an incredible basic recipe to expand upon. I didn't have any sour cream, but I had some heavy whipping cream and that seemed to work just fine. I divided this recipe in half before the sugar was added and made one half of the recipe vanilla flavored ( the half with the sugar added, only 1/2 cup). The other half i made with cheddar and asiago cheese and some cayenne pepper. Instead of trying to divide one egg for each half of the recipe I added one egg to each half.  I made some vanilla glaze from cream, vanilla and powdered sugar for the vanilla scones. Both varieties turned out beautifully. I know I will use this recipe again. I would like to add orange rind and use an orange juice glaze for the next batch. Thanks Grandma Johnson!!!!

I wouldn't change a thing. You can make a variety with the same batter. I seperate the dough in half. I used  1 tsp lemon rind, and added blueberries. The other half I put in 1 tsp vanilla extract and then added semi-sweet chocolate chips. All of them have been light, like a buscuit. They travel well without breaking up. text:
I wasn't sure whether to use cold butter and cut it in or softened butter. I went with the cold and the dough was very crumbly. I had to add a few tablespoons of heavy cream to get it to come together. I also added vanilla extract, sprinkled the tops with sugar before baking, and baked them longer (I made them big). Turned out fantastic with these changes.

text:
OH MY GOSH, these are AWESOME.  I did follow the tips from the reviewer Lucy 7 dated 9/13, thanks!  The only variations I made from hers were I omitted the raisins, still used 1c of sugar.  I made these for a Valentine's Day play group so I used a 3" heart cookie cutter which made around 32 hearts.  I also used the back of a 1/2 tsp to make a dip in the center and filled it with 1/4 tsp jam.  Don't put too much or they will over fill while baking :)  I got the jelly idea from Betty Crocker's website.  I can't wait to try them with fresh fruit.  I think you could add just about anything to these and you won't go wrong!

text:
Ahhhhh perfection! I am a pastry-eating junkie so trying to keep these out of my mouth is difficult! The changes I made were minimal. As a previous reviewer had mentioned, I added and extra 1/2 cup of sugar. I divided the dough into 2. In one half I added 1 tsp of cinnamon and 1 tsp vanilla extract. For those I also made a vanilla glaze with confectioners sugar, milk, vanilla extract and a touch of almond extract. The second section I put dried cranberries in and made an orange glaze for those with confectioners sugar, grated orange peel and orange juice. It was the perfect combo! This is only the first time I have tried this recipe, it was actually a test run for a baby shower I will be hosting in the near future. This surely passed the test and without hesitation I will be making these for the shower guests!!!!! Thank you!

Yummy! I added the zest of 1 orange and then squeeze some of the oranges juice in. I then cutthe batter in half and added chocolate chips to one batch and cranberries I soaked in warm water to the other.( I used Henry's strawberry flavored cranberries)I also beat the egg and added it to the sour cream mixture as well as 1tsp. of vanilla. *I found that using a silpat works wonderfully with baking these scones. Ugh. A total disaster. For starters, I didn't have baking powder, so I said to myself, "Self I says, google baking powder subs." And so I did. Two parts cream of tarter, one part baking soda. Well, it is kind of hard to divide 1 and .25 teaspoons into thirds. But I tried.  After combining the ingredients, I spread the dough out to knead it, and it's all dusty. It's not a dough, it's a ball of white dirt with clobs of butter in it. Ooops. Scoop up the stuff and put it back in the bowl. Jumping online I find to add 1 teaspoon of milk to help this problem, and I do so. It helps, so I spread it out again. Then I go to cut it. It won't stick together. Ooops. Back into the bowl, and more milk. Try to cut them again and it still won't stay together. Ooops. Or maybe it should be ARGH instead of ooops. By now I'm ready to throw the dough at the 4 year old who keeps saying "wah wah wah" to me as I struggle with the dough. ARGH. Now I just don't care any more. I grab a handful of the dough and ball it up and chunk onto the pan. Look ma, a new recipe, scone balls!

They're baking now,I'm scared to look into the oven. I can almost hear them yelling "You bloody fool!".

OK, on to the taste: YUM! I wee bit on the thick side, but that's OK. They're plenty sweet, even with reduced sugar. Worth the hassle? Tough call....

End result was a light, flaky scone, a result of the sour cream mixed with the baking soda and then the addition of cream of tartar. If I didn't have a recipe that I LOVED I certainly would have rated this a five.  I don't care for raisins (too big and flabby) so I swapped out for currants, made the glaze as pictured, which is an absolute "must have" addition in my opinion.  Grandma Johnson, you have a mighty fine recipe.  Mrs. Humphries, you're still my favoritest favorite.

These are really good, but... scones are funny business.  Kind of like biscuits... the preferred textures run a wide range, and one person's finest biscuit or scone may differ greatly from another's.  I personally liked these a lot, my kids did not.  They prefer them the way I have made them in the past... Grandma Johnson's scones are soft all the way through and just slightly chewy, the ones I normally make are slightly crunchy on the outside but completely tender inside.  To each his own.  This is an excellent recipe for those who prefer no crunch but want a hint of chewiness.

text:
YUMMY!! GREAT recipe- I'd never made scones before, but will definitely be making these again.
I made a few change. I accidently omitted the cream of tartar. I have no idea what it would actually do to make them any better, but they were delicious without it. I used fat free sour cream. I mixed all of the dy ingredients and cut in the cold butter until crumbly. I added the egg and a dash (1 tsp?) of vanilla to the sour cream/baking soda mixture right before adding it to dry ingredients. I kneaded it just enough to keep it together. I would suggest making two seperate cakes (or decreasing the recipe by half or the scones you make will be enormous) Mine baked for 15 minutes. I had some canned vanilla frosting which I melted in the microwave and drizzled over the top.
These scones were so tender and yummy we didnt use any butter or jam at all-they were perfect right out of the oven.

I made these last week ... and they are to die for! These tasted quite close to the scones sold at our popular Puyallup Fair here in Western WA! I did leave out the raisens, and I slice them open and put Raspberry Jam inside before serving. I tried something that worked pretty well (however right out of the oven is best). I took them to a womens gathering...they were nice and warm to serve although they were a bit more 'moist' because of the crock pot. Next time I will leave the lid ajar on the crockpot so the steam escapes better. Great recipe!

text:
Moist, sweet, flaky, tasty. Howver, not *exactly* like a scone should taste - this tastes more cake-like and is a tad too sweet. Also, I had to bake them far longer than the suggested 15 minutes. Like other users, I was able to divide the dough into four pieces and quarter each of them for 16 scones instead of 12. Next time, I will use 1/2-3/4 of the sugar, and try it with low-fat sour cream; I will also bake at 425 degrees for a faster bake time.

text:
Followed what another reviewer recommended and added the egg to the sour cream mixture  along with 1 teaspoon of vanilla. At the end, added orange zest from 2 oranges and 1 cup of dried cranberries (omitted the raisins). Once the scones were cooled drizzled an orange glaze made of 1/2 cup icing sugar, 1 tbsp orange juice, and 1/2 tsp orange zest over the scones. Next time if using a glaze on the scones would reduce the sugar in the scone recipe to 3/4 cup so that they don't get too sweet with a glaze added to them.

text:
These scones are amazing.  Some tips - the butter needs to be COLD.  I use a food processor to cut mine into the flour (put about half the flour/sugar mix into the processor, slice up all the butter into 1tbsp chunks and add them to the flour, then pulse until butter is cut in to desired size).  Also, once you add the sour cream and egg, if the mixture seems TOO dry or crumbly,  press it into a big mound in the bowl and let it rest for 3-4 minutes.  I generally add toffee or cinnamon chips at this stage, then knead dough to incorporate the chips, then roll out.

They did surprise even me: I love scones but I am usually defending them against detractors who are perpetually saying that scones are not really cakes, not really bread, not really worth the effort, not really satysfying enough and so on and so on. So yes, I am a regular scones champion, but this recipe brought them over the top. I just wanted to make this batch as plain as possible, I was in a hurry, I checked the pantry and no raisins, my husband was putting pressure as we were to go out... a culinary disaster in the making!  but oh my, these were no fuss and sooo gooood!!! instead of raisins I only had a mix of dried cranberries and raspberries, and didn't remember to add them till the dough was ready and packed. Maybe all this heartburn was the reason of the success of this recipe: minimum handling and baking. They were perfect, everyone was marveling on the light texture and the wonderful flakiness. Can't wait to try not all the fancy different combinations (lemon orange, white choc, and cinnamon, apples, and so on) only but strawberry jam and cream even.

Don't listen to the reviews that tell you to have butter at room temp.  It goes against every rule of a scone.  Those reviewers are making muffins.    Cold butter cut in small pieces then pulse in food processor with the flour  then take your fingers and flatten out butter.  (  biscuit method ).  They will turn out very fluffy   Give them plenty of room on cookie sheet  they do grow.

I have made this recipe several times. We really like it a lot. I make it as instructed. I usually add Craisins and orange zest. I have also added turbinado sugar or a glaze on top, too. I like them a little sweeter. 
You really do need to "cut in" the butter. You aren't supposed to cream it with the sugar. Cutting it in gives you the layers. Also, don't over mix the dough. When I make them, the texture is a lot like a soft, fluffy biscuit. They are so good warm out of the oven.

text:
This is my favorite scone recipe. I've been making it for years, usually subbing finely chopped dried cherries and candied ginger for the raisins. If I add more than the suggested one cup of dried fruit, i.e. 1/2 cup ginger and 1 cup cherries, then the dough becomes quite crumbly. Adding 1tsp of milk (or another liquid, like vanilla extract)  before kneading solves the problem. Bottom line: add 1tsp liquid for every extra 1/2 cup of dried fruit. Enjoy!

Before baking I sprinkled the top with large sugar crystals for a little extra sweetness and it looks nice. I also used another reviewers suggestion and made breakfast scones with shredded cheddar cheese and bacon. They were very good as well! I used 12 oz of bacon and shredded my cheese fine. I didn't measure the cheese so it may have been 1 c. Next time I will increase the bacon to at least 16 oz and shred the cheese using the bigger holes. I also only added 1/2 c. sugar in the breakfast scones and will use maybe 1/3 c. next time to cut the sweetness a bit. I only made 1/2 of each batch and froze the rest, before baking, so all I need to do is get a few out and bake for fresh scones anytime.

text:
I have discovered that, what Americans consider a scone, bears little resemblance to a traditional English or Scottish scone.  If you've had scones at your local coffee house, farmer's market, or bakery, this is probably a pretty close copy. If you've had tea at Harrod's in London, this scone is not even close.  These scones are sweeter and more cake-like; traditional scones are more like a dense biscuit, that's not really very sweet. That's not a criticism of this recipe, but of most scone recipes I've found. So, while this is not the recipe I was searching for, my kids are thrilled I've found this one- they love the lemon blueberry version, with a lemon glaze on top. It's exactly like the one they get from the farmer's market.

text:
I've made this recipe dozens of times now, and love it as-is or completely altered: less sugar, more sugar, chocolate chips, berries, cinnamon, etc.. I freeze my butter for about 10 minutes beforehand and grate it into the flour mixture with a cheese grater, then cut the butter in briefly with my fingers; it's faster than using a pastry cutter and keeping the butter cold seems to help keep the scones from spreading too much.  All four of my teenagers love these scones, which is a miracle in itself!

country:
None
text:
These came out beautifully, though were more like tiny cakes than scones. I live in Idaho, so maybe that has something to do with the consistency, but they were not at all dry. They really were like eating the sweetest, most moist biscuit. They were more dense than cake, but very soft and fall-apart in your mouth wonderful.
What I did was add some lemon zest to the sour cream mixture and let it set for an extra 10 min. I tore off a small amount of finished dough and flattened it with my fingers. Then I added as many fresh, plump blueberries as I could fit on top, then added another flattened dough disc. I gently pushed them together and turned the disc while squeezing the sides until they resembled inch thick biscuits. Baked for 18 minutes (and they really could have been in there for 20). Recipe yielded 11 5-inch "scones."

text:
Great recipe, first time I have made scones. I will definitely be making these again. I tried to make them healthier but still took into account other's edits, and this is what I came up with:

1 1/4 cup sugar
NO sour cream, instead used 2 single-serve 0% fage greek yogurts
Only used 1 stick of UNSALTED butter instead of 2

If you are making orange/cranberry: Add about 1 cup of dried cranberries & a shy 1/2 cup orange juice to mix. Made a glaze for the top with orange juice, milk, powdered sugar & cinnamon. I also added a teaspoon of cinnamon & 1/4 teaspoon of cloves to the dough, although my fianc did not like that. It is a matter of preference but as the "household scone expert," he told me cinnamon has no place in a cranberry/orange scone. Up to you!

text:
I can't rate these fairly as is, because I didn't follow the recipe exactly. When I read from some reviewers that the texture was more like a "muffin", I didn't want that. I wanted more of a crisp, crumbly texture. One reviewer recommended omitting the egg so as not to get that muffin kind of texture, so that's what I did differently.  Instead of the egg, I added 1/4 cup of milk in its place.  The dough was indeed very crumbly and hard to work with, but the end result was good, though still not as "dry" as I would have liked.  My husband LOVES them.  I added fresh blueberries instead of the raisins and baked them for 25 minutes (they are big).  I also gave them a quick brushing of egg white and a dusting of some course grained sugar on the top before baking, and that added a nice touch.

text:
Wonderfully simple, delicious and filled with endless possibilities. I divide the dough and use different fruits and/or berries. My favorite includes minced dried apricots and slightly chopped sweet coconut flakes. On this one I sprinkle some raw sugar granuals on top prior to baking. With the raisin batch I sprinkle with cinnamon/sugar. No butters and jellies needed to enjoy these. Individually wrapped after baking makes for a great, convenient morning coffee mate or afternoon tea treat. Next experiment will be using blueberries, adding in a cream cheese mixture topped with a yellow cake crumb topping. I did add 1/4 teaspoon of vanilla as suggested in another review. Everyone loves these.

text:
I made these as written and felt they were too sweet and biscuit-y.  So, for my second batch, I lessened the sugar to 3/4 cup and reduced the butter by 2T.  They were still a touch too sweet for my own tastes, but I felt the consistancy had much improved.  I patted my dough on a lightly floured surface and formed a rectangle.  From the rectangle, I cut squares and then sliced each square diagonally to form triangles.  Mine were golden brown on the bottom (and a bit around the edges) after 25 min, but they were still soft.  I left them on the counter, uncovered, overnight and the next morning they were nearly perfect.

very good but i don't think if i made all the changes that were suggested they would have been. I did as someone suggested with adding baking soda to sour cream and setting arsde then mixing butter sugar(i did an extra 1/4 c. of sugar) eggs and 1 T. vanilla and setting aside then mixing all the dry. text:
I've made these scones a few times, each time to rave reviews!  I do freeze the butter and then process the ingredients in my food processor to make it easier.  First mix all the dry ingredients, add the frozen butter that you have cut up into approx. 6 pieces. Mix well by pulsing the dough until choppy.  Then mix wet ingredients in a separate bowl and add the ingredients together.  

One note - I didn't had sour cream so I used plain yogurt.  They needed more flour and were too sweet.  I wouldn't recommend using that substitute!

Fantastic.  I have made these a number of times, most recently for the day after Thanksgiving breakfast for the whole family. I like to add b. powder to s.cream and then whisk all dry ingredients.  Next I cut in cold butter, then add egg to s.cream mixture, whisk and gently blend into dry (using my hands after a few mixes).  Finally I add in chopped dried fruit (trader joes mix of cherry, blueberry & strawberry) dump onto floured surface, knead a few times, pat out and cut. text:
I made these scones today, they tasted great but they were not exactly what I was looking for.  They were very light and fluffy.  A little cake-like.  I was hoping for a more dense and flaky scone.  I followed the directions exactly and I think that this recipe just produces scones are just lighter and fluffier.  Like I said they taste excellent, just not exactly what I was expecting or looking for.  Also, the dough became hard to work with when it was time to cut and shape them.  The dough was very sticky and a little too soft to really be able to cut into them.  I read another review on another scone recipe and it said that after you add the wet to the dry ingredients to put the mixture in the freezer for a few minutes to get the butter to solidify a bit before cutting.  I will try that next time, although I will probably try it with another recipe as I just want a more dense and flaky scone.  Good recipe though.

text:
I tried this recipe and was quite pleased with it. The scones were moist and tasty but slightly different texture then most scones. I used 1 cup of brown flour and 3 cups white flour, also substituted white sugar for brown sugar. I split the dough and added orange zest and raisins to one batch and added mixed berries (blueberry, raspberries and blackberries) and lemon zest to other batch. Both varieties were very good. I will make it again and may substitute 1/4 to 1/2 cup of the flour for oatmeal next time, if they are supposed to be for breakfast then they should have some nutritional tweaks I think!

text:
We loved them! I substituted dried cherries and white chocolate chips for the raisins (about 3/4 c. each). Also brushed with egg wash and sprinkled with demerara sugar because we like that crunchy top. I use a metal dough scraper to cut them into twelfths, works great. Also use a non-stick liner, so don't have to grease the pan. As other reviewers noted, handle the dough as little as possible, knead only until it all comes together, then press into a large even circle before cutting. Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Very good recipe, but not overwhelmingly great.  I found these scones to be more like biscuits (as in bisquick) in texture and flavor instead of the scones I'm used to, which is slightly drier and more firm.  That may just be my prejudice due to my previous favorite scone recipe, though.  Don't let my review deter you from making these - I've made several batches and I can attest that adding any of these things to the scone recipe works great:  Fresh blueberries, fresh raspberries, currants, diced apple (add a little cinnamon to the recipe for apples), and maple/brown sugar topping (mix brown sugar with good quality maple syrup until a very thick paste is made, depress scone in the middle with a spoon to create a dent and fill with maple/brown sugar mixture. Bake as normal, but be careful, the mixture will run. Yum!)

Pretty good. Not AMAZING, although I think that had to do with me. I had a messy sticky dough and I was stressed out that I was over working it. Some of the other reviewrs said to add more sugar- DO NOT. I did one and a quarter cup sugar and it was really sweet. Tasty, but too sweet for a scone if you ask me. And I used quarter teasp lemon juice instead of cream of tarter.  Once the dough was workable I rolled it out into a quarter inch sheet, cut it into rectangles, put a couple fresh rasberries inside and folded it over (potsticker style) and pinched the edges closed. Its really tasty that way. Finished scone was tender even if I did work the dough to death.

text:
Nice taste, the texture is more biscuit like. I believe I could have achieved the same result with bisquick or pioneer baking mix. Ive had a hard time finding a really good scone recipe so rather than risk another flop, I decided to cut the recipe in half so that I didnt end up with a wastebasket full of scones. I then divided this mixture and  made 3 varieties. I made 4 scones with blueberries, 2 scones with cinnamon chips and 2 scones with cherry flavored dried cranberries and white choc. chips. I glazed the blueberry and the cinnamon chip scones with a simple glaze, flavored with vanilla. For the cranberry/white chocolate scones I made the orange glaze. The blueberry was by far the best.

region:

country:

text:
Very easy and quick!  I made these for an office breakfast and I had so many people  coming up to me saying how great they were.  I reduced the sugar to 3/4 cup and added 1 tsp. of vanilla. I also used an egg wash to allow the tops to brown nicely.  I highly recommend using a pastry cutter to cut in the butter.  Also, divide the dough into thirds and make 3 circles to cut into triangles.  If not the scones are way too big! In order to make sure that they were nice and fresh that morning I made up the dough the night before and cut  into triangles and placed on the greased cookie sheet and placed the whole thing in the freezer.  In the morning all I had to do was cut on the oven and take the pan out of the freezer to bake.  It did take a bit longer to cook, but they were still warm when they were served (and I got to sleep in a little later!) 
  I divided the recipe into thirds and tried 4 flavors in two batches: Plain, Raisin (topped with cinnamon sugar), white chocolate cranberry, and chocolate chip (used  60% cocoa chips). The favorites were the raisin and chocolate chip. Everyone one of the scones were eaten and my husband was so disappointed that there were no leftovers that I have to make another batch just for him!

text:
These turned out very tasty, but I don't know if I made them right.  It seemed like there was too much flour, I think next time I'll try three cups instead of four.  There didn't seem like there was enough moisture to wet all the dough and I had alot of loose flour and dough falling all over the place.  I added 2tsp cinnamon, 1/2 cup walnuts and 2 T. extra sugar to the dough to make cinnamon scones, and then topped them with a white glaze (3/4cup powdered sugar and 5 tsp. milk) They are really good, especially with a cup of tea!! Like I said, I don't know if I made them exactly right.  I've only made scones once or twice in my life SEVERAL years ago, so I'm sure I need to work on technique and stuff.
